sen.j: 汁粉（しるこ）は、主に小豆を砂糖で甘く煮て、この中に餅や白玉団子、クリの甘露煮などを入れた食べ物。
sen.e: Shiruko is a food made by cooking red beans with sugar which is served with mochi (rice cakes) or shiratama dango (Japanese rice-flour dumplings) topped with stewed chestnuts in syrup.

Shiruko is a food whose main ingredient is boiled red beans sweetened with sugar, and in which mochi (rice cake), shiratama dango (Japanese rice-flour dumplings), and chestnuts stewed in syrup are added.

Shiruko is a food whose main ingredient is boiled red beans sweetened with sugar, and in which mochi (rice cake), shiratama dango (Japanese rice-flour dumplings), and chestnuts stewed in syrup are added.

sen.j: おしることも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also referred to as oshiruko.
It is also referred to as oshiruko.
It is also referred to as oshiruko.

sen.j: 汁粉は餡（あん）の違いによって区別される場合が多い。
sen.e: Shiruko is often categorized by how an (bean paste) is prepared.
Shiruko is often categorized by how an (bean paste) is prepared.
Shiruko is often categorized by how an (bean paste) is prepared.

sen.j: 基本的なものはこの3種類である。

sen.j: 御前汁粉
sen.e: Gozen jiruko
Gozen jiruko
Gozen jiruko

sen.j: – 漉（こ）し餡を用いている。
sen.e: - Smooth bean paste made by passing the beans through a sieve is used.
- Strained bean paste (smooth bean paste made by passing the beans through a sieve) is used.
sen.cmt: strained bean pasteを説明に追加
sen.e: - Strained bean paste (smooth bean paste made by passing the beans through a sieve) is used.

sen.j: 田舎汁粉
sen.e: Inaka jiruko
Inaka jiruko
Inaka jiruko

sen.j: – つぶし餡を用いている。
sen.e: - Bean paste made from coarsely mashed beans is used.
- Bean paste made from coarsely mashed beans is used.
- Bean paste made from coarsely mashed beans is used.

sen.j: 小倉汁粉
sen.e: Ogura jiruko
Ogura jiruko
Ogura jiruko

sen.j: – 粒餡を用いている。
sen.e: - Beans used for this type of shiruko are not mashed to retain the grain of beans intact.
- Tsubuan (coarsely-mashed sweet bean paste containing pieces of adzuki bean's skin) is used.
- Tsubuan (coarsely-mashed sweet bean paste containing pieces of adzuki bean's skin) is used.

sen.j: 関西などで用いられるぜんざい（善哉）の語は田舎汁粉あるいは小倉汁粉の事を指し、汁粉という言葉は漉し餡を用いた御前汁粉についてのみ用いられる。
sen.e: The term 'zenzai' used in areas including the Kansai district means either Inaka jiruko (country style sweet bean soup) or Ogura jiruko and the term 'shiruko' specifically refers to Gozen jiruko made from the strained bean paste.

The term 'zenzai' used in areas including the Kansai district means either Inaka jiruko (country style sweet bean soup) or Ogura jiruko and the term 'shiruko' specifically refers to Gozen jiruko made from the strained bean paste.

The term 'zenzai' used in areas including the Kansai district means either Inaka jiruko (country style sweet bean soup) or Ogura jiruko and the term 'shiruko' specifically refers to Gozen jiruko made from the strained bean paste.

sen.j: 汁粉には種類も多く、こうした基本的なものの他に以下のような物がある。
sen.e: There are various types of shiruko including the ones as described below in addition to those basic varieties that have been previously mentioned.
There are various types of shiruko including the ones as described below in addition to those basic varieties that have been previously mentioned.

sen.j: 粟ぜんざい
sen.e: Awa Zenzai
Awa Zenzai
Awa Zenzai

sen.j: – 粟餅に濃い目の漉し餡をかけたもの。
sen.e: - Awa zenzai is made by pouring the thick smooth bean paste over mochi made of millet.
- Awa zenzai is made by pouring the thick strained bean paste over mochi made of millet.
sen.cmt: 漉し餡をstrained bean paste(上記）と訳出し
sen.e: - Awa zenzai is made by pouring the thick strained bean paste over mochi made of millet.

sen.j: 懐中汁粉
sen.e: Kaichu Jiruko
Kaichu Jiruko
Kaichu Jiruko

sen.j: – 最中の皮の中に粉末の漉し餡とあられを入れた日本古来のインスタント食品。
sen.e: - It is an ancient Japanese fast food consisting of shells made of wafer filled with bean jam.
- It is an ancient Japanese fast food consisting of a wafer shell filled with powder of strained bean paste and arare (cubic rice crackers).
- It is an ancient Japanese fast food consisting of a wafer shell filled with powder of strained bean paste and arare (cubic rice crackers).

sen.j: 湯を掛けて溶いて食べる。
sen.e: To eat Kaichu jiruko, pour some hot water over and it will be ready.
To eat Kaichu jiruko, pour some hot water over and it will be ready.

sen.j: クリームぜんざい
sen.e: Cream Zenzai (Zenzai with ice cream)
Cream Zenzai (Zenzai with ice cream)
Cream Zenzai (Zenzai with ice cream)

sen.j: – 粒餡の汁粉を冷やし、その上からソフトクリームやアイスクリームといった冷たい西洋菓子をのせた物。
sen.e: - Place either soft ice cream or regular ice cream on top of the chilled shiruko made of coarsely mashed beans.
- Place either soft ice cream or regular ice cream on top of the chilled shiruko using tsubuan.
- Place either soft ice cream or regular ice cream on top of the chilled shiruko using tsubuan.

sen.j: 地方料理の一環として、小豆以外に白餡、栗、かぼちゃ、百合根、枝豆（ずんだ）を用いて作る場合もある（山梨県には「小豆ぼうとう」と呼ばれる餅の代わりにほうとうを入れたものもある）
sen.e: As a local specialty, shiruko is sometimes made from white haricot beans, chestnuts, winter squash, edible lily bulbs or green soybeans (and in Yamanashi Prefecture, there is also a type of shiruko known as the 'azuki boto' in which hoto (wheat flour noodle dough cut into small pieces) is substituted for rice cakes.

As a local specialty, shiruko is sometimes made from white haricot beans, chestnuts, winter squash, edible lily bulbs or green soybeans (and in Yamanashi Prefecture, there is also a type of shiruko known as 'azuki boto' in which hoto (wheat flour noodle dough cut into small pieces) is substituted for rice cakes.

As a local specialty, shiruko is sometimes made from white haricot beans, chestnuts, winter squash, edible lily bulbs or green soybeans (and in Yamanashi Prefecture, there is also a type of shiruko known as 'azuki boto' in which hoto (wheat flour noodle dough cut into small pieces) is substituted for rice cakes.

sen.j: 高知県とその周辺でよく作られる皿鉢料理では、甘味の料理として小倉汁粉が鉢に盛って出され、ぜんざいと称される。
sen.e: With the celebrated Sawachi-ryori (assorted cold food served on a large plate) commonly prepared in Kochi Prefecture and its surrounding areas, the ogura jiruko is served in a bowl as a sweet dish which is referred to as the zenzai.

In Sawachi-ryori (an assorted cold food served on a large plate) celebrated and commonly prepared in Kochi Prefecture and its surrounding areas, the ogura jiruko is served in a bowl as a sweet dish which is referred to as zenzai.

sen.j: 作り方はほぼ普通の小倉汁粉と同じだが、餅や白玉団子の代わりに、鳴門巻きや蒲鉾、ホウボウなどの茹でた魚が丸ごと入れられる事もある。
sen.e: The recipe for the above-mentioned zenzai is virtually identical to that for the ordinary ogura jiruko but, in some cases, naruto-maki (kamaboko with the pattern of the well-known tidal whirlpools off the shore of Naruto City), kamaboko (boiled fish paste cake) or a whole boiled fish such sea robin substitutes for rice cakes or rice flour dumplings.

The recipe for the above-mentioned zenzai is virtually identical to that for the ordinary ogura jiruko but, in some cases, naruto-maki (kamaboko with the pattern of the well-known tidal whirlpools off the shore of Naruto City), kamaboko (boiled fish paste cake) or a whole boiled fish such sea robin substitutes for rice cakes or rice flour dumplings.

The recipe for the above-mentioned zenzai is virtually identical to that for the ordinary ogura jiruko but, in some cases, naruto-maki (kamaboko with the pattern of the well-known tidal whirlpools off the shore of Naruto City), kamaboko (boiled fish paste cake) or a whole boiled fish such sea robin substitutes for rice cakes or rice flour dumplings.

sen.j: 日本古来からある食べ物らしく、砂糖の無い時代、小豆本来の持つ甘みを楽しむために考案された料理の一つと言われている。
sen.e: It seems that shiruko has been in existence since ancient times in Japan and it is said to be one of the dishes conceived in days before sugar became available to enjoy the natural sweetness of red beans.

It seems that shiruko has been in existence since ancient times in Japan and it is said to be one of the dishes conceived in days before sugar became available to enjoy the natural sweetness of red beans.

It seems that shiruko has been in existence since ancient times in Japan and it is said to be one of the dishes conceived in days before sugar became available to enjoy the natural sweetness of red beans.

sen.j: 江戸時代の寛永12年（1635年）の『料理物語』の後段（宴会の後に出される間食で、うどんやそうめん、饅頭などが含まれる）の欄に、「すすりだんご」と称される物が載っている。
sen.e: In the column designated for the godan (epilogue) (dessert served after a banquet including udon noodles, somen noodles, manju (bun stuffed with red bean jam) in Ryori Monogatari (Tales of Food) written in 1635, a dish referred to as 'susuridango' was mentioned.

A dish referred to as 'susuridango' is mentioned in a column describing godan (dessert served after a banquet including udon noodles, somen noodles, manju (a bun stuffed with red bean jam) in "Ryori Monogatari" (Tales of Food) written in 1635.

A dish referred to as 'susuridango' is mentioned in a column describing godan (dessert served after a banquet including udon noodles, somen noodles, manju (a bun stuffed with red bean jam) in "Ryori Monogatari" (Tales of Food) written in 1635.

sen.j: これはもち米6に対しうるち米4で作った団子を小豆の粉の汁で煮込み、塩味を付けたものであり、その上から白砂糖をかける。
sen.e: To make the 'susuridango,' cook dumplings made of 6 parts mochi-gome (glutinous rice with its carbohydrate molecule consisting of 100% amylopectin) and 4 parts uruchi-mai (glutinous rice with its carbohydrate molecule consisting of 80% amylopectin and 20% amylose) in the red bean flour soup, add salt to taste, sprinkle some sugar on top and serve.

To make the susuridango, stew dumplings made of mochi-gome (glutinous rice with its carbohydrate molecule consisting of 100% amylopectin) and uruchi-mai (glutinous rice with its carbohydrate molecule consisting of 80% amylopectin and 20% amylose) in a red bean flour soup, while the ratio of mochi-gome and uruchi-mai in the dumpling is six to four, add salt, then sprinkle some sugar.

To make the susuridango, stew dumplings made of mochi-gome (glutinous rice with its carbohydrate molecule consisting of 100% amylopectin) and uruchi-mai (glutinous rice with its carbohydrate molecule consisting of 80% amylopectin and 20% amylose) in a red bean flour soup, while the ratio of mochi-gome and uruchi-mai in the dumpling is six to four, add salt, then sprinkle some sugar.

sen.j: 一種の汁物である。
sen.e: The 'susuridango' is a type of soup.
The susuridango is a type of soup.
The susuridango is a type of soup.

sen.j: 当初は甘い物ではなく、塩味で調理されており、酒の肴として用いられる事もあった。
sen.e: It was originally not a sweet dish but was seasoned with salt, sometimes being served as accompaniment to sake.
It was originally not a sweet dish but was seasoned with salt, sometimes being served as an accompaniment to sake.
It was originally not a sweet dish but was seasoned with salt, sometimes being served as an accompaniment to sake.

sen.j: 後述する島根県での雑煮における汁粉も、元来はこうした塩味の料理であったと考えられる。
sen.e: It is considered that the shiruko as described later in conjunction with the zoni (New Year's special soup with rice cake as the main ingredient) served in Shimane Prefecture under 'Other' was originally a savory dish as well.
The shiruko eaten in Shimane Prefecture as zoni (New Year's special soup with rice cake as a main ingredient), which will be described later, is considered to have originally been a savory dish.
The shiruko eaten in Shimane Prefecture as zoni (New Year's special soup with rice cake as a main ingredient), which will be described later, is considered to have originally been a savory dish.

sen.j: 餡餅やおはぎなどとの関連性もあるものと見られる。
sen.e: It seems that the shiruko is related to some other food such as anmochi (rice dumplings coated with sweet red beans) and ohagi (rice balls coated with sweet red beans, roasted soybean flour or sesame seeds).

It seems that the shiruko is related to some other food such as anmochi (rice dumplings coated with sweet red beans) and ohagi (rice balls coated with sweet red beans, roasted soybean flour or sesame seeds).

It seems that the shiruko is related to some other food such as anmochi (rice dumplings coated with sweet red beans) and ohagi (rice balls coated with sweet red beans, roasted soybean flour or sesame seeds).

sen.j: なお、「すすりだんご」と称するものは現在でも大分県等に残っており、トウモロコシ粉団子の汁粉を指したり、団子を野菜と煮たすいとんのような料理を指す事もある。
sen.e: The food referred to as 'susuridango' still remains in existence in some areas including Oita Prefectures which sometimes means shiruko with corn flour dumplings or stew with dumplings and vegetables.

The food referred to as 'susuridango' still remains in existence in some areas including Oita Prefecture, where the susuridango sometimes means shiruko with corn flour dumplings or a dish like suiton (a dish made of dumplings stewed with vegetables).

The food referred to as 'susuridango' still remains in existence in some areas including Oita Prefecture, where the susuridango sometimes means shiruko with corn flour dumplings or a dish like suiton (a dish made of dumplings stewed with vegetables).

sen.j: 現在は甘みを増して喫茶店や甘味屋・茶店などで供されている。
sen.e: At present, the heavily sweetened shiruko is being served at various places such as tea parlors, Japanese sweet parlors and tea stands.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: At present, the heavily sweetened shiruko is being served at various places such as tea parlors, Japanese sweet parlors and tea stands.
At present, the heavily sweetened shiruko is being served at various places such as tea parlors, Japanese sweet parlors and tea stands.

sen.j: 大阪の「夫婦善哉」（白玉団子の御前汁粉が2つの小さな御椀に入れられて供される）、仙台のずんだ汁粉など地域色の出た汁粉が出されている。
sen.e: Shiruko may have characteristics specific to the respective region in some areas such as 'Meoto Zenzai' (consisting of 2 small bowls of gozen-jiruko with rice flour dumplings) in Osaka and Zunda Shiruko (sweet green soybean soup with rice cakes or rice flour dumplings) in Sendai.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Some shiruko have region-specific characteristics such as 'Meoto Zenzai' (consisting of two small bowls of gozen-jiruko with rice flour dumplings) in Osaka and Zunda Shiruko (sweet green soybean soup with rice cakes or rice flour dumplings) in Sendai.

Some shiruko have region-specific characteristics such as 'Meoto Zenzai' (consisting of two small bowls of gozen-jiruko with rice flour dumplings) in Osaka and Zunda Shiruko (sweet green soybean soup with rice cakes or rice flour dumplings) in Sendai.

sen.j: 特に甘味屋や茶店においては、口直しや甘味を際立たせるものとして、塩昆布や漬物など塩味の濃い食品を添えて出す事が多い。
sen.e: At Japanese sweet parlors and tea stands, in particular, the salty shiokonbu (kelp cooked in brine and soy sauce) or Japanese pickles is often served with shiruko to break the monotony of the sweet taste of shiruko or to enhance the sweetness of shiruko.

At Japanese sweet parlors and tea stands, in particular, salty shiokonbu (kelp cooked in brine and soy sauce) or Japanese pickle is often served with shiruko to break the monotony of the sweet taste of shiruko or to enhance the sweetness of shiruko.
sen.cmt: salty shiruko の前のtheを削除。Japanese picklesをJapanese pickleに変更。
sen.e: At Japanese sweet parlors and tea stands, in particular, salty shiokonbu (kelp cooked in brine and soy sauce) or Japanese pickle is often served with shiruko to break the monotony of the sweet taste of shiruko or to enhance the sweetness of shiruko.

sen.j: また、長崎の卓袱料理においては「梅椀」という名で御前汁粉がデザートとして出される。
sen.e: With the Shippoku Cuisine (special Chinese cuisine developed in Nagasaki Prefecture to which Japanese cooking methods were incorporated), gozen-jiruko under the name of 'Ume Wan' is served as dessert.
In Shippoku Cuisine (special Chinese cuisine developed in Nagasaki Prefecture into which Japanese cooking methods were incorporated), gozen-jiruko under the name of 'Ume Wan' is served as dessert.
sen.cmt: 前置詞の変更(Withを In, toを into）
sen.e: In Shippoku Cuisine (special Chinese cuisine developed in Nagasaki Prefecture into which Japanese cooking methods were incorporated), gozen-jiruko under the name of 'Ume Wan' is served as dessert.

sen.j: 梅椀という名前は梅の花の塩漬けを汁粉に浮かべて出したからともいわれる。
sen.e: It is said that the term Ume Wan came from the practice in which shiruko was served with salt-preserved plum flowers floating on the top.
It is said that the term Ume Wan came from the practice in which shiruko was served with salt-preserved plum flowers floating on the top.
It is said that the term Ume Wan came from the practice in which shiruko was served with salt-preserved plum flowers floating on the top.

sen.j: 砂糖が貴重品だった時代の名残ともいわれるが、古い時代の卓袱料理の献立では汁粉以外の菓子類等が出されており、確証は無い。
sen.e: It is said that Ume Wan is a legacy from times when sugar was a precious commodity but, according to the menus of the Shippoku Cuisine in ancient times, some sweets other than shiruko were also served and hence this opinion remains inconclusive.

It is said that Ume Wan is a legacy from times when sugar was a precious commodity, but according to the menus of the Shippoku Cuisine in ancient times, some sweets other than shiruko were also served; hence this opinion remains inconclusive.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置の見直し
sen.e: It is said that Ume Wan is a legacy from times when sugar was a precious commodity, but according to the menus of the Shippoku Cuisine in ancient times, some sweets other than shiruko were also served; hence this opinion remains inconclusive.

sen.j: また、冬場になると、従来からの懐中汁粉のようなものでカップラーメンのようにカップにお湯を注いで作る「即席汁粉」や、缶入りでジュースのようにそのまま飲むことができる「汁粉ドリンク」などが店頭に見られるようになる。
sen.e: During the winter, the 'instant shiruko,' which, much like the cup ramen (instant Chinese noodles in a cup), is ready when hot water has been poured and is similar to the conventional kaichu jiruko and the 'shiruko drink' which comes in a tin and is ready to serve just like canned juice are on display at store front.

During the winter, 'instant shiruko,' similar to the conventional kaichu jiruko, which becomes ready for eating with hot water having been poured in the cup just like the cup ramen (instant Chinese noodles in a cup), and 'shiruko drink' which comes in a can ready for drinking just like canned juice are provided in the store.

During the winter, 'instant shiruko,' similar to the conventional kaichu jiruko, which becomes ready for eating with hot water having been poured in the cup just like the cup ramen (instant Chinese noodles in a cup), and 'shiruko drink' which comes in a can ready for drinking just like canned juice are provided in the store.

sen.j: 鏡開きにおいては、一般家庭でも鏡餅を用いて汁粉や善哉を作る。
sen.e: On the occasion of Kagamibiraki (the annual ritual of cutting and eating a large, round rice cake, which has been offered to the gods to celebrate the new year, on January 11), Japanese people make shiruko or zenzai using Kagamimochi (large, round rice cake offered to the gods) at home.

On the occasion of Kagamibiraki (an annual ritual of cutting and eating a large, round rice cake, which has been offered to the gods to celebrate the new year, on January 11), Japanese people make shiruko or zenzai using Kagamimochi (large, round rice cake offered to the gods) at home.
sen.cmt: the annual ritualを an annual ritual に変更
sen.e: On the occasion of Kagamibiraki (an annual ritual of cutting and eating a large, round rice cake, which has been offered to the gods to celebrate the new year, on January 11), Japanese people make shiruko or zenzai using Kagamimochi (large, round rice cake offered to the gods) at home.

sen.j: 正月の代表的な食べ物の一つ。
sen.e: It is one of the representative foods for the New Year season.
It is one of the representative foods for the New Year season.
It is one of the representative foods for the New Year season.

sen.j: 島根県や鳥取県においては雑煮として正月に汁粉を食べる風習がある。
sen.e: In Tottori Prefecture and Shimane Prefecture, there is a custom to eat shiruko as zoni on the New Year's Day.
In Tottori Prefecture and Shimane Prefecture, there is a custom to eat shiruko as zoni on the New Year's Day.

sen.j: また香川県など四国の一部では雑煮に餡入りの餅が使用される。
sen.e: In some areas of the Shikoku region such as Kagawa Prefecture, rice cakes stuffed with red bean jam is used in zoni.
In some areas of the Shikoku region such as Kagawa Prefecture, rice cakes stuffed with red bean jam is used in zoni.

sen.j: 沖縄県では「ぜんざい」の語は汁粉の一種でなく、主に砂糖で煮たインゲンマメの上に氷を盛ったかき氷を指す。
sen.e: In Okinawa, 'zenzai' is not a type of shiruko but means a snow cone with sweet stewed haricot beans and ice shavings on top.
In Okinawa, 'zenzai' is not a type of shiruko but means a shaved ice made of shaved ice topped with haricot beans stewed mainly with sugar.
In Okinawa, 'zenzai' is not a type of shiruko but means a shaved ice made of shaved ice topped with haricot beans stewed mainly with sugar.

sen.j: ぜんざい沖縄県のぜんざいを参照。
sen.e: See 'Zenzai' in Okinawa Prefecture for more details.
See 'Zenzai' in Okinawa Prefecture for more details.

sen.j: 汁粉に類似した食品は中国やベトナムにもあり、栗やハスの実、タピオカ団子を中に入れたりする。
sen.e: There is food similar to shiruko in China and Vietnam that is served with chestnuts, lotus fruit or tapioca dumplings.
There is food similar to shiruko in China and Vietnam that is served with chestnuts, lotus fruit or tapioca dumplings.
There is food similar to shiruko in China and Vietnam that is served with chestnuts, lotus fruit or tapioca dumplings.

sen.j: 黒ゴマやココナッツミルクの餡を用いたデザートがあるが、日本の汁粉との関連性はよく分かっていない。
sen.e: Additionally, there is dessert made from sweet bean paste with black sesame seeds or coconut milk in these countries but the relationship between those food items and Japanese shiruko remains unknown.
Additionally, there is dessert made from sweet bean paste of black sesame seeds or coconut milk in these countries, but the relationship between those food items and Japanese shiruko is unknown.
